Posts.Content: Nice toiletries with lavender - smells lovely and helps you to relax. Bath and shower, hand and foot cream too. Easy reading books, magazines to flick through when concentrating is difficult, and just the people you want to have around.
Posts.Title: Supporting my SIL

Posts.Content: Hi SFGS Monday will seem a long time away at the moment so yes, ring your BCN and describe your symptoms. There’s nothing to be lost by doing that and it will alleviate your worry to some extent at least. Pain in the night isn’t good, lack of sleep makes things worse, and the imagination runs riot!  No doubt the nurse will confer with the oncologist if she needs to. A good nurse is worth her (his?) weight in gold. Hope you feel better soon. Take care.
Posts.Title: Constant worrying

Posts.Content: Hi Suzy, I changed oncologists after 10 months - my confidence in the first one and the whole team was gradually worn away. In my case that actually meant changing hospitals but it was the best decision I could have made as the new place is great and I feel much better cared for and supported. I did some research and then asked my GP to refer me elsewhere. It wasn’t a problem, no difficult questions asked, patients have a right to second opinions and to be treated where they choose. Hope that helps.
Posts.Title: Has anyone changed oncologist mid treatment?

Posts.Content: Hello Annie I decided to have a look at this thread to see if the side effects from Paclitaxel were shared with anyone and they obviously are! So I sympathise with the blocked and (this morning bleeding) nose, the dodgy stomach and the achy legs, although I’ve not had the cystitis so far.  I don’t know about you, but I get paranoid about it all - are they side effects or symptoms of something else happening so it’s reassuring to find someone with similar stuff going on. I’ve had 3 doses so far with the next one due Thursday. I’ve a clinic appointment first so I have a list of side effects to tell them about, including a rash on my hands which started after being in the garden and getting a couple of insect bites which flared up. The GP gave me steroid cream for that and it’s starting to disappear.  I have to trust that it’s the best way forward as you say but it’s hard sometimes to believe that putting all this chemical stuff into my body is good! Thanks for your positive take on it all.
